tei.text:
Surface Molecular Self-Assembly for
Organophosphate Pesticide Imprinting in
Electropolymerized Poly(p-aminothiophenol)
Membranes on a Gold Nanoparticle Modified
Glassy Carbon Electrode
Chenggen Xie,* , † Huaifen Li, † Shanqi Li, † Ju Wu, † and Zhongping Zhang* , ‡
Department of Chemistry and Life Science, West Anhui University, Lu'an, Anhui 237012, P. R. China, and Institute of
Intelligent Machines, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Hefei, Anhui 230031, P. R. China
This paper reports a surface molecular self-assembly strat-
egy for molecular imprinting in electropolymerized polyami-
nothiophenol (PATP) membranes at the surface of gold
nanoparticles (AuNPs) modified glassy carbon (gc) electrode
for the electrochemical detection of pesticide chlorpyrifos
(CPF). Electropolmerizable p-aminothiophenol (ATP) was
first assembled on the AuNPs at the gc electrode surface
by the formation of Au-S bonds, and subsequently, the CPF
template was further assembled onto the monolayer of ATP
through the hydrogen-bonding interaction between amino
group and CPF. A conductive hybrid membrane was fabri-
cated at the assembled gc electrode by the electropolymer-
ization in a mixing solution containing additional ATP and
CPF templates, and meanwhile, the CPF was spontaneously
imprinted into the PATP/AuNP film. The amount of im-
printed sites at the PATP/AuNP film was significantly
increased due to the additional replenishment of CPF
templates. The cyclic voltammetric response of the im-
printed PATP-AuNP-gc sensor to CPF is about 3.2-fold as
compared with the imprinted PATP-Au sensor, and the
detection limit for CPF is about 2 orders of magnitude lower
than that by the imprinted PATP-Au sensor. An excellent
electrochemical selectivity for CPF over other pesticides was
also achieved. The combination of surface molecular self-
assembly with electropolymerized molecular imprinting on
a larger surface area of a AuNP-modified electrode produces
a high ratio of imprinted sites and, thus, provides an
ultrasensitive electrochemical detection of organophosphate
pesticide.
Organophosphate pesticide chlorpyrifos (CPF) is widely used
in agriculture, household, and urban insecticide applications,
because of its high toxicity as an inhibitor of acetylcholinesterase
that is necessary for normal function of nervous system. 1 The
residue of CPF in agricultural products and the natural environ-
ment is extremely harmful to human health and zoology. Up to
now, various methods have already been proposed to assay CPF
and its metabolites by the use of complicated instruments such
as gas chromatography with mass spectrometry (GC/MS)
detection 2-4 and liquid chromatography with mass spectrometry
(LC/MS). 5-7 However, these instrumental analysis are usually
expensive, time-consuming, and tedious, and require sample
pretreatment and highly trained technical personnel. On the other
hand, enzyme/antibody-based immunoassay has also been de-
veloped for the detection of organophosphate CPF 8-14 by the
readout of various electrochemical or optical transducers, such
as voltammetric response, 15,16 surface plasmon resonance (SPR), 17,18
and optical approach. 19-21 Although a high sensitivity can be
achieved, the poor chemical/physical stability of the antibodies
* To whom correspondence should be addressed. E-mail: cgxie@wxc.edu.cn
(C.X.); zpzhang@iim.ac.cn (Z.Z.).
† West Anhui University.
‡ Chinese Academy of Sciences.

934.

877, 568.
(8) Banks, K. E.; Hernandez, S. Talanta 2003, 61, 257.

(10) Gabaldó n, J. A.; Maquieira, A.; Puchades, R. Talanta 2007, 71, 1001.
(11) Velasco-Arjona, A.; Manclú s, J. J.; Montoya, A.; Luque de Castro, M. D.
Talanta 1997, 45, 371.
(12) Heilmair, R.; Eyer, F.; Eyer, P. Toxicol. Lett. 2008, 181, 19.
(13) Istamboulie, G.; Fournier, D.; Marty, J. L.; Noguer, T. Talanta 2009, 77,
1627.

2008, 133, 195.
(15) Viswanathan, S.; Radecka, H.; Radecki, J. Biosens. Bioelectron. 2009, 24,
2772.
(16) Istamboulié , G.; Andreescu, S.; Marty, J. L.; Noguer, T. Biosens. Bioelectron.
2007, 23, 506.
(17) Mauriz, E.; Calle, A.; Lechuga, L. M.; Quintana, J.; Montoya, A.; Manclú s,
J. J. Anal. Chim. Acta 2006, 561, 40.
(18) Solanki, P. R.; Prabhakar, N.; Pandey, M. K.; Malhotra, B. D. Biomed.
Mircrodevices 2008, 10, 757.
(19) Simonian, A. L.; Good, T. A.; Wang, S. S.; Wild, J. R. Anal. Chim. Acta
2005, 534, 69.
(20) Prabhakar, N.; Arora, K.; Singh, S. P.; Pandey, M. K.; Singh, H.; Malhotra,
B. D. Anal. Chim. Acta 2007, 589, 6.
(21) Prabhakar, N.; Sumana, G.; Arora, K.; Singh, H.; Malhotra, B. D. Electrochim.
Acta 2008, 53, 4344.
Anal. Chem. 2010, 82, 241-249
10.1021/ac901860t  2010 American Chemical Society
241
Analytical Chemistry, Vol. 82, No. 1, January 1, 2010
Published on Web 11/25/2009
or enzymes prevents their use in the harsh environments of acids
or bases, organic solvents, and high temperatures. Accordingly,
it still remains a great challenge to develop a rapid, inexpensive
but sensitive method for the detection of CPF in environments.
Recently, numerous attempts have been made to replace
biological receptors with synthetic counterparts as a recognition
element in chemo/biosensors. Of various approaches, the mo-
lecular imprinting technique has become a powerful tool for the
preparation of polymeric materials that have the ability to specif-
ically bind a chemical species. 22,23 Molecular imprinting typically
involves the preassembly of template molecule and functional
monomer and the subsequent copolymerization with cross-linking
monomers. The removal of template molecules from the polymer
matrix generates the recognition sites (cavities) complementary
to the shape, size, and functionality of the template molecule. 24-29
Because of mechanical/chemical stability, low cost, and easy
preparation, molecularly imprinted materials have widely been
used as sensitive components in chemical/biological sensors for
pesticide detection. 30,31 For the construction of the molecularly
imprinted polymer (MIP)-based sensor, the molecularly imprinted
membranes can be synthesized in situ at an electrode surface by
an electropolymerization technique 32 at the surface of gc
electrode, 33,34 gold electrode, 35,36 graphite electrode, 37 etc. It is
well-known that the sensitivity of the imprinted sensor is dictated
by the amount of effective imprinted sites on the sensor surface.
Although the amount of the imprinted sites increases with the
increase of the imprinted membrane thickness, thick imprinted
membranes can lead to slow diffusion of the analytes to the
recognition sites and to inefficient communication between the
binding sites and transducers. 38 To further increase the amount
of effective imprinted sites on the sensor surface, the simplest
method is to use a higher surface area electrode, 39 through the
assembly of gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) at the surface of
electrodes 40-43 due to its large specific surface area, good
biocompatibility, and high conductivity. 44
Herein, we report a surface molecular self-assembly strategy
for molecular imprinting in electropolymerized aminothiophenol
(ATP) membranes at the AuNP-modified gc electrode for the
electrochemical detection of pesticide CPF. The combination of
surface molecular self-assembly with electropolymerization of ATP
on a larger area of AuNP-modified electrode was expected to
produce a high ratio of imprinted sites and to enhance the total
amount of effective imprinted sites. The electrochemical sensor
not only can strikingly improve the sensitivity and selectivity of
CPF analysis but also obtains good repeatability and, thus, can
be potentially exploited for the detection of pesticide residuals or
other deleterious chemicals in environment.
EXPERIMENTAL SECTION
Reagents. Figure 1 displays the structural formulas of the
pesticide compounds used in this study. Chlorpyrifos (CPF) and
2,4-dichlorophenoxy acetic acid (2,4-D) were purchased from
Fluka. Other pesticides were kindly provided by Anhui Huaxing
Chemical Industry Co., Ltd. p-Aminothiophenol (ATP) was ob-
tained from Alfa Aesar. Tetarachloroaurate (III) acid (HAuCl 4 )
and potassium ferricyanide (K 3 Fe(CN) 6 ) were purchased from
Shanghai Chemicals Ltd. Other reagents were commercially
available as analytical reagent grade and used without further
purification. Stock solutions of 1.0 × 10 -2 M pesticide were
prepared in acetonitrile and stored at 4°C in a refrigerator to
avoid exposure to light. Phosphate buffer solution (PBS, pH
) 6.86, 0.05 M) was prepared from KH 2 PO 4 and K 2 HPO 4 with
doubly distilled water. KCl (0.1 M) was used as the supporting
electrolyte.
(22) Haupt, K.; Mosbach, K. Chem. Rev. 2000, 100, 2495.
(23) Dickert, F. L.; Lieberzeit, P.; Tortschanof, M. Sens. Actuators, B: Chem.
2000, 65, 186.
(24) Stevenson, D. TrAC, Trends Anal. Chem. 1999, 18, 154.
(25) Andersson, L. I. J. Chromatogr., B 2000, 739, 163.
(26) Wulff, G. Chem. Rev. 2002, 102, 1.
(27) Xie, C. G.; Zhang, Z. P.; Wang, D. P.; Guan, G. J.; Gao, D. M.; Liu, J. H.
Anal. Chem. 2006, 78, 8339.
(28) Xie, C. G.; Liu, B. H.; Wang, Z. Y.; Gao, D. M.; Guan, G. J.; Zhang, Z. P.
Anal. Chem. 2008, 80, 437.
(29) Gao, D. M.; Zhang, Z. P.; Wu, M. H.; Xie, C. G.; Guan, G. J.; Wang, D. P.
J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2007, 129, 7859.
(30) Blanco-Ló pez, M. C.; Lobo-Castañó n, M. J.; Miranda-Ordiers, A. J.; Tuñó n-
Blanco, P. Trends Anal. Chem. 2004, 23, 36.
(31) Marx, S.; Zaltsman, A.; Turyan, I.; Mandler, D. Anal. Chem. 2004, 76, 120.
(32) Malitesta, C.; Losito, I.; Zambonin, P. G. Anal. Chem. 1999, 71, 1366.
(33) Liu, Y.; Song, Q. J.; Wang, L. Microchem. J. 2009, 91, 222.
(34) Liu, X. Y.; Li, C. Y.; Wang, C. F.; Li, T.; Hu, S. H. J. Appl. Polym. Sci. 2006,
101, 2222.
(35) Liao, H. P.; Zhang, Z. H.; Li, H.; Nie, L. H.; Yao, S. Z. Electrochim. Acta
2004, 49, 4101.
(36) Li, J. P.; Zhao, J.; Wei, X. P. Sens. Actuators, B: Chem. 2009, 140, 663.
(37) Ö zcan, L.; Ş ahin, Y. Sens. Actuators, B: Chem. 2007, 127, 362.
(38) Riskin, M.; Tel-Vered, R.; Bourenko, T.; Granot, E.; Willner, I. J. Am. Chem.
Soc. 2008, 130, 9726.
(39) He, X. L.; Yuan, R.; Chai, Y. Q.; Shi, Y. T. J. Biochem. Biophys. Methods
2008, 70, 823.
(40) Daniel, M. C.; Astruc, D. Chem. Rev. 2004, 104, 293.
(41) Yu, A.; Liang, Z.; Cho, J.; Caruso, F. Nano Lett. 2003, 3, 1203.
(42) Liu, S.; Li, X. H.; Li, Y. C.; Li, Y. F.; Li, J. R.; Jiang, L. Electrochim. Acta
2005, 51, 427.
(43) Feng, Y. Y.; Yang, T.; Zhang, W.; Jiang, C.; Jiao, K. Anal. Chim. Acta 2008,
616, 144.
(44) Xu, S. Y.; Han, X. Z. Biosens. Bioelectron. 2004, 19, 1117.
Figure 1. Structural formulas of the pesticide compounds used in this study.
242
Analytical Chemistry, Vol. 82, No. 1, January 1, 2010
Apparatus. Electrochemical measurements were performed
using an electrochemical analyzer LK98B∏ (Tianjin, China)
connected to a personal computer. A three-electrode configuration
was employed, consisting of a bare or modified gc electrode (2
mm in diameter) as a working electrode and an Ag/AgCl/
saturated KCl electrode and a platinum wire (1 mm in diameter)
as the reference electrode and auxiliary electrode, respectively.
Preparation of AuNP-gc Electrode. A gc electrode was
polished carefully to a mirrorlike surface with 0.3-0.05 µm of
alumina aqueous slurry and then successively washed in an
ultrasonic cleaner with water and ethanol. Prior to the deposition
of AuNPs, the bare gc electrode was cyclic-potential scanned in
the potential range -0.2 to +0.6 V in 0.01 M K 3 [Fe(CN) 6 ] solution
containing 0.1 M KCl supporting electrolyte until a pair of well-
defined redox peaks was observed. To electrochemically
deposit AuNPs on the surface of the gc electrode, the gc
electrode was immersed in 0.2 g L -1 HAuCl 4 solution and
treated by the use of a constant potential of -0.2 V for 60 s. 45-48
After being cleaned with acetone, ethanol, and doubly distilled
water, the AuNP modified gc electrode (AuNP-gc) was immersed
in a fresh piranha solution (H 2 SO 4 /H 2 O 2 , 7:3) for about 5 min,
rinsed again with doubly distilled water, and finally dried under
nitrogen gas. Caution: The piranha solution is dangerous to
human health and should be used with extreme caution and
handled only in a small quantity.
ATP Modification and CPF Self-Assembly on a AuNP-gc
Electrode. ATP modification was carried out by methods that
were reported in the literature. 49-51 The pretreated AuNP-gc
electrode was immersed into a 10 mM solution of ATP in ethanol.
After a reaction period of 24 h at room temperature, the electrode
was taken out and rinsed with ethanol and water. Then, the ATP-
modified AuNP-gc electrode was immersed into a 1 mM solution
of CPF in acetonitrile for 6 h. The electrode was taken out, rinsed
with ethanol, and then dried under nitrogen flow at the room
temperature. CPF molecules accordingly assembled onto the ATP-
modified AuNP-gc electrode through hydrogen bond interactions
between the residual amino groups (-NH 2 ) of ATP and the
nitrogen/oxygen atom of CPF.
Preparation of Imprinted PATP-AuNP-gc Electrode. The
ATP-modified AuNP-gc electrode with CPF assembly on the
electrode surface was immersed in the aqueous electrolyte
solution containing 5 mM ATP, 0.1 M KCl, 0.1 mM CPF, and 0.05
M PBS (pH ) 6.86). After the solution was deoxygenated by
bubbling nitrogen gas for about 15 min, the electropolymerization
was performed by seven consecutive cyclic scans in the potential
range of -0.2 and +0.6 V at a scan rate of 50 mV s -1 . After the
electropolymerization, the polyaminothiophenol (PATP) mem-
brane modified AuNP-gc electrode (PATP-AuNP-gc) was rinsed
with 0.5 M HCl three times for 20 min each to remove the
CPF template. Then, the imprinted PATP-AuNP-gc electrode
was rinsed with doubly distilled water and ethanol and dried
under nitrogen for further use. At the same time, the imprinted
PATP membrane modified gold (PATP-Au) electrode (2 mm
in diameter) was also produced under identical chemical
conditions. As a control, the nonimprinted PATP-AuNP-gc
electrode was prepared and treated in the same way except
that the template molecule was omitted from electropolymer-
ization stage.
Electrochemical Measurements. The imprinted PATP-AuNP-
gc electrode was dipped into 0.1 M KCl containing the desired
concentration of CPF for 10 min, washed with doubly distilled
water carefully to remove the possible adsorptive substances on
the electrode surface, and then transferred to the electrochemical
cell containing 0.05 M PBS (pH ) 6.86) and 0.1 M KCl as the
supporting electrolyte. Before electrochemical measurements,
the electrolyte solution was purged with nitrogen for 10 min. The
cyclic voltammogram was recorded between -1.0 and +1.2 V at
a scan rate of 100 mV s -1 . The electrochemical impedance
spectroscopy was scanned in 0.01 M Fe(CN) 6
3-/4-and 0.1 M
KCl solution at the formal potential of 0.25 V with a frequency
range of 1-10 5 Hz and a signal amplitude of 5 mV. All
measurements were performed at room temperature.
RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
Figure 2A illustrates the preparation procedures of the im-
printed PATP-AuNP-gc electrode. The preparation procedures
were summarized as three steps: electrodeposition of AuNPs on
the surface of gc electrode; electropolymerization of ATP on the
surface of AuNP-gc electrode; removal of the imprinting CPF
molecules from the imprinted PATP membranes. Prior to the
electropolymerization, the deposition of AuNPs was performed
on the gc electrode surface in the 0.2 g L -1 HAuCl 4 solution by
the use of a constant potential of -0.2 V. The deposition time
was used to control the amount of AuNPs on the gc electrode
for obtaining an adequate coverage of AuNPs on the gc
electrode surface. The ideal deposition time was determined
by measuring the voltammetric response of corresponding
electrodes in 0.01 M K 3 [Fe(CN) 6 ] and 0.1 M KCl solution. The
results showed that the redox peak currents of Fe(CN) 6
3-/4-
were the strongest with the first 60 s deposition and then
decreased slowly with deposition time. Although the longer
deposition time could increase the amount of AuNPs on the gc
electrode surface, aggregations of AuNPs on the gc electrode
surface would decrease the surface area of AuNPs, leading to the
decrease of redox peak current of Fe(CN) 6
3-/4-
. As illustrated
in Figure 2B, when the AuNP-gc electrode was immersed into a
10 mM solution of ATP in ethanol for 24 h at room temperature,
a self-assembled monolayer (SAM) of ATP molecules was formed
on the AuNP surface by Au-S bonds between AuNPs and the
thiol groups (-SH) of ATP molecules. 49-51 The SAM of ATP can
serve as an initial polymerizable monolayer to improve the
"wetting" of the surface by the polymer, 52 which drives the
selective occurrence of electropolymerization at the surface of
AuNPs.
On the other hand, when the ATP-modified AuNP-gc electrode
was immersed into a 1 mM solution of CPF in acetonitrile for
(45) Matharu, Z.; Arya, S. K.; Sumana, G.; Gupta, V.; Malhotra, B. D. J. Mol.
Recognit. 2008, 21, 419.
(46) Liu, S. F.; Wang, L.; Zhao, F. J. Electroanal. Chem. 2007, 602, 55.
(47) Kim, G. Y.; Shim, J.; Kang, M. S.; Moon, S. H. J. Environ. Monit. 2008,
10, 632.
(48) Lu, L. P.; Wang, S. Q.; Lin, X. Q. Anal. Chim. Acta 2004, 519, 161.
(49) Riskin, M.; Tel-Vered, R.; Bourenko, T.; Granot, E.; Willner, I. J. Am. Chem.
Soc. 2008, 130, 9726.
(50) Rubinstein, I.; Rishpon, J.; Sabatani, E.; Redondo, A.; Gottesfeld, S. J. Am.
Chem. Soc. 1990, 112, 6135.
(51) Huang, Z. F.; Chen, F.; Bennett, P. A.; Tao, N. J. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2007,
129, 13225.
(52) Sabatani, E.; Gafni, Y.; Rubinstein, I. J. Phys. Chem. 1995, 99, 12305.
243
Analytical Chemistry, Vol. 82, No. 1, January 1, 2010
6 h. CPF molecules in solution phase could be assembled onto
the ATP-modified AuNP-gc electrode through hydrogen bond
interactions between the residual amino groups (-NH 2 ) of ATP
and nitrogen/oxygen atom of CPF. The intermolecular interac-
tion between ATP and CPF could be confirmed by UV
absorbance spectra. The maximum absorption wavelength of
ATP slightly shifted to red wavelength in the presence of CPF,
and the maximum absorbance of ATP was also largely
increased with the addition of CPF (Figure 3). These suggest
the formation of hydrogen bond interactions between the amino
group (-NH 2 ) of ATP and the nitrogen/oxygen atom of CPF
in the solution system. Therefore, the strong hydrogen bond
interactions would drive CPF molecules to assemble onto the
surface of the ATP-modified AuNP-gc electrode. These CPF
molecules assembled onto the ATP-modified AuNP-gc elec-
trode surface were embedded into the imprinted PATP mem-
branes and formed surface imprinted sites, which would
increase the amount of imprinted sites on the electrode surface
and enhance the sensitivity of the electrode. Our detailed
experiments also reveal that if the preincubation step was
omitted from the preparation procedures of the imprinted
PATP-AuNP-gc electrode, the cyclic voltammetric responses
to CPF would decrease to about 10%-20% under the same
experimental condition.
The imprinted PATP membranes were electrodeposited onto
the ATP-modified AuNP-gc electrode surface in the 0.1 M KCl
solution containing 5 mM ATP and 0.1 mM CPF by the scanning
potential between -0.2 and +0.6 V for seven consecutive cycles
at a scan rate of 50 mV s -1 . Figure 4A shows representative cyclic
voltammograms for electropolymerization process of ATP on the
ATP-modified AuNP-gc electrode surface in the presence of CPF.
The voltammetric behavior of ATP showed that it was an entirely
irreversible oxidation process. An oxidation peak of ATP was
clearly observed at a potential of 0.48 V on the first scan. Then,
the anodic peak current decreased slightly under a continuous
cyclic scan. Finally, the peak currents almost became stable after
a seven-cycle scan. Moreover, the oxidation peak potential of ATP
slightly shifted to more anodic potentials from 0.48 to 0.53 V. The
results indicate that electro-oxidation of the ATP monomer
occurred at the anode and the PATP membranes deposited onto
the surface of the AuNP-gc electrode. The decrease of the peak
current seems to be related with the continual formation of PATP
membranes that leads to the suppression of the voltammetric
response. The SEM image in Figure 4B confirms the formation
of PATP/AuNP membranes on the AuNP-gc electrode surface.
The rough surface provides a large surface area for the adsorption
of target species at the modified electrode. In addition, similar
cyclic voltammograms of the electropolymerization processes of
ATP on the AuNP-gc electrode surface in the absence of CPF
had also been observed. Meanwhile, there is not any difference
in the cyclic voltammograms obtained in the presence/absence
of CPF template, indicating that CPF does not exhibit any
electroactivity in the potential range chosen for the polymerization
and its structure was not electrochemically altered during elec-
tropolymerization.
Figure 2. (A) Preparation procedures of the imprinted PATP-AuNP-gc electrode: (1) electrodeposition of AuNPs on the surface of the gc
electrode; (2) electropolymerization of ATP on the surface of the AuNP-gc electrode; (3) removal/rebinding of CPF on the imprinted sites of the
imprinted PATP-AuNP-gc electrode. (B) Schematic illustrations for the adsorption of the ATP molecule at the AuNP surface and the further
self-assembly of CPF at ATP-modified AuNP-gc electrode.
Figure 3. Evolution of UV spectra with increasing different amounts
of CPF into 10 µM ATP solution.
244
Analytical Chemistry, Vol. 82, No. 1, January 1, 2010
In order to confirm whether CPF molecules had been embed-
ded in the imprinted PATP membranes, cyclic voltammograms
of the imprinted PATP-AuNP-gc electrode before and after the
removal of the imprinted CPF molecules as well as the nonim-
printed PATP-AuNP-gc electrode were, respectively, recorded in
the N 2 -saturated PBS containing KCl solution as supporting
electrolyte (Figure 5). Before the removal of the imprinting CPF
molecules, a very sharp and well-defined oxidation peak at ∼0.93
V and two broad and small reduction peaks at ∼0.23 V and ∼-0.65
V were clearly recorded with the imprinted PATP-AuNP-gc
electrode (Figure 5a). However, the nonimprinted PATP-AuNP-
gc electrode only exhibited a broad and small reductive peak at
∼-0.70 V, and no oxidation peak at ∼0.93 V was observed in the
cyclic voltammogram (Figure 5c). Since the electrochemical
measurements were carried out in CPF-free solutions, it is clearly
confirmed that the strong oxidation peak (E pa ) ∼0.93 V) was
entirely due to the oxidation reaction of CPF molecules
embedded into the imprinted PATP membranes. From the
imprinting procedures used in this work, there are two types
of imprinted sites in the imprinted PATP/AuNP membranes.
First, CPF molecules were assembled onto the ATP-modified
AuNP-gc electrode surface in advance through hydrogen bond
interactions between the residual amino groups (-NH 2 ) of ATP
and CPF molecules, forming surface imprinted sites. Second,
CPF templates in the solution of the electropolymerization
precursors were further embedded inside the PATP/AuNP
membranes and formed interior imprinted sites because of the
formation of hydrogen bonds between the amino group (-NH 2 )
of ATP and the nitrogen/oxygen atom of CPF in the solution
system. Therefore, the combination of surface molecular self-
assembly with the electropolymerization technique was ex-
pected to produce a high ratio of imprinted sites and to enhance
the total amount of effective imprinted sites.
Furthermore, the CPF embedded in the PATP membranes
could be efficiently removed from the PATP membranes by
rinsing with 0.5 M HCl solution three times for 20 min each. As
shown in Figure 5b, the characteristic oxidation peak of CPF
molecules disappeared completely after the rinsing process, and
the cyclic voltammogram became almost identical to that of the
nonimprinted PATP-AuNP-gc electrode (Figure 5c). Therefore,
electrochemical polymerization of ATP can give rise to the
recognition sites complementary to the molecular shape, size, and
functionality of CPF molecules.
Obviously, in comparison with the voltammetric behavior for
the electropolymerization process of ATP (Figure 4A), no oxida-
tion peak at ∼0.48 V was observed in the cyclic voltammograms
of the imprinted PATP-AuNP-gc electrode, and the nonimprinted
PATP-AuNP-gc electrode (Figure 5b,c, respectively). The results
indicate that the PATP membranes are difficult to be oxidized
under this experimental condition, which can effectively avoid an
interference with CPF signal and enhance sensitivity of CPF. Our
detailed experiments reveal that the pH of the solution has a
significant influence on the stability of the imprinted PATP
membrane. At more acidic and basic pH, there is a strong
background signal resulting from the PATP polymer in the scan
range, producing a strong interference with the CPF signal to
make the detection of the CPF signal difficult. Therefore, in this
work, the mixture solution of PBS (0.05 M, pH ) 6.86) and 0.1 M
KCl was used for all electrochemical experiments.
Figure 6A shows the cyclic voltammograms of K 3 [Fe(CN) 6 ]
at the bare gc electrode, AuNP-gc electrode, imprinted PATP-
AuNP-gc electrode, and nonimprinted PATP-AuNP-gc elec-
trode. The cyclic voltammogram at the bare gc electrode
showed a quasi-reversible redox reaction with the peak
potential difference (∆E P ) of 140 mV and the ratio of the peak
Figure 4. (A) Cyclic voltammograms for the electropolymerization of 5 mM ATP at the ATP-modified AuNP-gc electrode surface in 0.1 M KCl
solution containing 0.1 mM CPF: scan rate, 50 mV s -1 ; sweep cycle, 7. (B) Typical SEM image of the imprinted PATP membrane formed with
seven consecutive potential cycles on the ATP-modified AuNP-gc electrode surface.
Figure 5. Cyclic voltammograms of the imprinted PATP-AuNP-gc
electrode before (a) and after (b) the removal of CPF and of (c) the
nonimprinted PATP-AuNP-gc electrode in the N 2 -saturated PBS (0.05
M, pH ) 6.86) containing 0.1 M KCl as supporting electrolyte. Scan
rate: 100 mV s -1 .
245
Analytical Chemistry, Vol. 82, No. 1, January 1, 2010
currents of about 1:1, respectively (Figure 6A, curve a). The
cyclic voltammetric peak currents increased after the AuNP
deposition onto the gc electrode surface (Figure 6A, curve b).
The peak current increase may be contributed to a small increase
of surface roughness and effective surface area. Meanwhile, the
anodic peak potential (E pa ) shifted to the negative direction
followed by the decrease in the peak potential difference (∆E P ).
The negative shift of anodic peak potential (E pa ) was due to
the electrocatalytic effect of the AuNPs, which lowered the
activation energy of electrochemical reaction and then facili-
tated the redox reaction of Fe(CN) 6
3-
/ 4-at the AuNP-gc
electrode.
Moreover, cyclic voltammograms were also employed to verify
the formation of the PATP membranes on the AuNP-gc electrode
surface. Curve c and d in Figure 6A showed the cyclic voltam-
mograms of the AuNP-gc electrode modified with the imprinted
PATP membranes and the nonimprinted PATP membranes under
the same condition. As expected, almost no electrochemistry
response could be observed with the nonimprinted PATP-AuNP-
gc electrode (Figure 6A, curve d). This is likely because electron
transfer was blocked by the PATP membranes which completely
covered the surface of the AuNP-gc electrode. However, after the
removal of template CPF molecules from the imprinted PATP
membranes, a pair of redox peaks was recorded as shown in Figure
6A, curve c. This suggested that cavities were produced in the
imprinted PATP membranes after the removal of template CPF
molecules. The porosity enhanced the diffusion of Fe(CN) 6
3-/4-
through the imprinted PATP membranes and promoted the
redox reaction of Fe(CN) 6
3-/4-on the electrode surface. In
comparison with the cyclic voltammogram of the AuNP-gc
electrode (Figure 6A, curve b), it can be found that the redox
peak potential difference (∆E P ) remarkably increased and the
redox peak currents evidently decreased. The results indicate
that the imprinted PATP membranes had assembled on the
AuNP-gc electrode surface and retarded the electron transfer
between the electrolyte and the electrode.
On the other hand, the electrochemical impedance spectros-
copy is an effective method for probing the features of a surface-
modified electrode. In the electrochemical impedance spectros-
copy, the semicircle portion at higher frequencies corresponds
to the electron-transfer limited process and the linear portion at
lower frequencies may ascribe to diffusion. The semicircle
diameter equals the electron-transfer resistance (R et ), which
depends on the dielectric and insulating features at the
electrode/electrolyte interface. 18,36,48 Curves a and b in Figure
6B showed the electrochemical impedance spectra of the bare
gc electrode and the AuNP-gc electrode, respectively. Almost
straight lines were exhibited, which were characteristic of a mass
diffusional limiting electron-transfer process. 53,54 The results show
faster electron-transfer kinetics of Fe(CN) 6
3-/4-on the bare gc
electrode and AuNP-gc electrode. However, after the PATP
membranes were electrodeposited onto the AuNP-gc electrode
surface (Figure 6B, curve c and d), the impedances were
significantly enlarged and the semicircle diameters of the im-
printed PATP-AuNP-gc electrode and the nonimprinted PATP-
AuNP-gc electrode were about 923 and 2900 Ω, respectively.
These results indicate PATP membranes have the larger obstruc-
tion effect, which results in reducing electron-transfer rate or
increasing resistance to the flow of electrons. Furthermore, in
comparison with the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy of
the nonimprinted PATP-AuNP-gc electrode (Figure 6B, curve d),
the semicircle diameters of the imprinted PATP-AuNP-gc electrode
(Figure 6B, curve c) was much less than that of the nonimprinted
APTP-AuNP-gc electrode. The reason may be that there were
large numbers of the imprinted cavities of CPF in the imprinted
PATP membranes, which enhanced the diffusion rate of Fe-
(CN) 6
3-/4-through the PATP membranes and made it easier
for electron transfer to take place.
We tested the electrochemical response of the imprinted PATP-
AuNP-gc electrode to the CPF analyte by the comparison with
the bare gc, AuNP-gc, nonimprinted PATP-AuNP-gc, and im-
printed PATP-Au electrode. Figure 7 shows the cyclic voltammo-
grams of the bare gc, AuNP-gc, the imprinted PATP-AuNP-gc,
nonimprinted PATP-AuNP-gc, and imprinted PATP-Au electrodes
to 6.0 × 10 -6 M CPF. The bare gc electrode exhibited a broad
and small reductive peak at ∼0.32 V and a very weak oxidative
peak at 0.87 V (Figure 7a), suggesting a bad sensitivity to CPF.
When the gc electrode was modified with the AuNPs, an obvious
oxidation peak of CPF at ∼0.98 V was observed (Figure 7b) due
to the large surface area and good electrocatalytic activity of

5574.
(54) Liu, Y.; Yu, Y. Y.; Yang, Q. Y.; Qu, Y. H.; Liu, Y. M.; Shi, G. Y.; Jin, L. T.
Sens. Actuators, B: Chem. 2008, 131, 432.
Figure 6. (A) Cyclic voltammograms of 0.01 M K 3 [Fe(CN) 6 ] and 0.1 M KCl at (a) bare gc electrode, (b) AuNP-gc electrode, (c) imprinted
PATP-AuNP-gc electrode, and (d) nonimprinted PATP-AuNP-gc electrode. Scan rate: 100 mV s -1 . (B) The electrochemical impedance spectra
of 0.01 M Fe(CN) 6
3-/4-and 0.1 M KCl at (a) bare gc electrode, (b) AuNP-gc electrode, (c) imprinted PATP-AuNP-gc electrode, and (d) nonimprinted
PATP-AuNP-gc electrode. The frequency range is between 1 and 10 5 Hz with signal amplitude of 5 mV.
246
Analytical Chemistry, Vol. 82, No. 1, January 1, 2010
AuNPs. After the imprinted PATP membranes were further
modified onto the AuNP-gc electrode surface, we clearly observed
a very strong and well-defined oxidation peak at ∼0.85 V and broad
and small reduction peaks at ∼0.03 V (Figure 7c). The anodic
peak current of the imprinted PATP-AuNP-gc electrode is about
7.3-fold compared to that of the AuNP-gc electrode. Meanwhile,
the anodic peak potential shifted to more negative potentials from
0.98 to 0.85 V with the modification of the imprinted PATP
membrane, which may result from the catalytic activity of the
imprinted matrix to the oxidation of CPF entering in the imprinted
sites. With regard to the sensitivity of determination of CPF, the
oxidation peak at 0.85 V was selected for quantitative analysis
because this peak was the most separated and intense.
Moreover, the imprinted PATP-Au electrode exhibited a well-
defined oxidation peak at ∼0.94 V and broad and small reduction
peaks at ∼0.24 V in 6.0 × 10 -6 M CPF (Figure 7e). With a
comparison with the imprinted PATP-AuNP-gc electrode (Figure
7c), the anodic peak current was decreased greatly by ap-
proximately 3.2-fold and was accompanied by a positive shift of
90 mV in the anodic potential direction. On the other hand, there
was no anodic signal of CPF observed at the nonimprinted PATP-
AuNP-gc electrode (Figure 7d). These above comparisons suggest
that the much higher sensitivity to CPF by the imprinted PATP-
AuNP-gc electrode should be mainly attributed to two advantages:
(i) the AuNPs provide a conductive roughened surface and have
a good electrocatalytic activity toward the oxidation reaction of
CPF and (ii) a high ratio of imprinted sites by the molecular self-
assembly greatly improves the enrichment of electrode to CPF
species in solution.
It is known that the amount of the imprinted PATP on the
AuNP surface strikingly influences the amount of CPF molecules
embedded into the PATP membranes. However, if the imprinted
PATP membranes are too thick, template molecules situated at
the central area of the PATP membranes cannot completely be
removed from the polymer matrix. Moreover, the imprinted sites
situated at the central area are difficult to access by target
molecules due to the high mass-transfer resistance. As a result,
thick imprinted polymer membranes would exhibit low binding
capacity, poor site accessibility, and slow binding kinetics. 27-29
Thus, the formation of thinner polymer membranes on the
electrode surface is preferred to improve the sensitivity of the
imprinted membranes. 55 The thickness of polymer membranes
can easily be adjusted by controlling the number of cycles during
the electropolymerization process. Figure 8 shows the evolution
of the peak current of CPF oxidation at the imprinted AuNP-gc
electrode with different scanning cycles in the imprinting elec-
tropolymerization. The voltammetric response to CPF obviously
rises and reaches a maximum with the seven cycles and then
decreases with a further increase of cycle number. Therefore,
seven cycles can obtain a suitable membrane thickness to provide
the highest sensitivity to CPF analyte.
The accumulation step is usually a simple and effective way of
enhancing the sensitivity of the imprinted sensor. 56 After template
molecules were removed from the imprinted PATP membranes,
the imprinted PATP electrode was preconcentrated in a stirring
0.1 M KCl solution containing 6.0 × 10 -6 M CPF before
measurement. Figure 9 shows the change of the anodic peak
current with the preconcentration time. The anodic peak current
increased significantly with the increase of preconcentration time
at the initial stage, and a stable response was obtained after 10
min, suggesting that the adsorption equilibrium was reached.
Thus, the preconcentration time of 10 min before the determina-
tion of CPF can obtain the strongest electrochemical response.
The selectivity of the imprinted PATP-AuNP-gc electrode to
CPF was evaluated by testing its cyclic voltammotric responses

Blanco, P. Trends Anal. Chem. 2004, 23, 36.
(56) Liu, G. D.; Lin, Y. H. Anal. Chem. 2005, 77, 5894.
Figure 7. Cyclic voltammograms of (a) the bare gc electrode, (b)
AuNP-gc electrode, (c) imprinted PATP-AuNP-gc electrode, (d)
nonimprinted PATP-AuNP-gc electrode, and (e) the imprinted PATP-
Au electrode in the presence of 6.0 × 10 -6 M CPF in 0.05 M PBS
(pH ) 6.86) and 0.1 M KCl. Scan rate: 100 mV s -1 .
Figure 8. Effect of the scanning cycles on the cyclic voltammetric
response of the imprinted PATP-AuNP-gc electrode to 6.0 × 10 -6
M CPF in 0.05 M PBS (pH ) 6.86) and 0.1 M KCl. Scan rate: 100
mV s -1 .
247
Analytical Chemistry, Vol. 82, No. 1, January 1, 2010
in the presence of some possible interfering substances including
methyl parathion (MP), methamidophos (MA), triazophos (TAP),
cartap (CP), and 2,4-dDichlorophenoxy acetic acid (2,4-D), re-
spectively. The selectivity of the imprinted PATP-AuNP-gc elec-
trode to CPF molecules was evaluated by calculating the peak
current ratio (I s /I 0 ), where I s and I 0 were anodic peak current
of CPF at 0.85 V in the present and absence of interfering
substances. As shown in Figure 10, a 10-fold excess of MP, MA,
TAP, CP and 2,4-D over CPF hardly causes the significant change
of peak current of CPF, in which peak current ratio only slightly
varied from 0.95 to 1.06. These results indicate that the imprinted
PATP-AuNP-gc electrode showed higher recognition selectivity
for CPF than for other pesticides. This may be explained by the
fact that the delicate recognition sites of CPF molecules in the
imprinted PATP membranes have the capability to recognize
target molecules, allowing the detection of CPF from a complex
matrix without separation. On the other hand, the reproducibility
of the measurements was evaluated by measuring the cyclic
voltammeric responses of 6.0 × 10 -6 M CPF at the same
imprinted PATP-AuNP-gc electrode. The relative standard
deviation (RSD) for seven successive determinations is about
2.3%. The imprinted PTAP-AuNP-gc electrode was stored under
desiccated conditions at room temperature when not in use.
The lifetime of the imprinted electrode was investigated by
measuring the voltammetric responses for 6.0 × 10 -6 M CPF
every 3 days. The response of the imprinted electrode de-
creased to 90% after storing for 30 days, and 82% of the original
responses were retained after 90 days. Furthermore, our
detailed experiments reveal that the response of CPF at the
imprinted PATP-AuNP-gc electrode hardly changed after the
imprinted electrode was used at least 50 times with subsequent
washing and measuring operations.
Figure 11 displays the cyclic voltammetric responses of the
imprinted PATP-AuNP-gc electrode to CPF after being precon-
centrated in CPF solution. The sharp and well-defined peak
current increased with CPF concentration. A calibration curve
between the anodic peak current at 0.85 V and the CPF concentra-
tion was exhibited in the inset of Figure 11. As can be seen, at
the high concentration range, the anodic peak currents tend to
be stable, indicating that the imprinting sites were almost occupied
by CPF molecules. A linear relationship between the anodic peak
current and CPF concentration was obtained covering the con-
centration range from 5.0 × 10 -7 to 1.0 × 10 -5 M; the linear
regression equation is I (µA) ) 26.80 + 10.93C (µM), with a
correlation coefficient of 0.9968. The detection limit is calcu-
lated to be 3.3 × 10 -7 M based on the 3σ of the blank signals.
However, with the imprinted PATP-Au electrode as a working
electrode, the linear range, the detection limit, and the standard
deviation for 1.0 × 10 -5 M CPF were 5.0 × 10 -5 M to 1.0 × 10 -4
M, 2.5 × 10 -5 M, and 3.6% (n ) 7), respectively. Therefore, the
detection limit for CPF by the imprinted PATP-AuNP-gc
electrode is about 2 orders of magnitude lower than that by
the imprinted PATP-Au electrode. Moreover, the proposed
method was utilized for the determination of CPF in environ-
mental water samples. The environmental water samples were
directly spiked with 6.0 × 10 -6 M in tap water. The results show
that the recoveries from the environmental water samples were
excellent and varied from 90.5% to 107.3%. Therefore, the
method may be applicable to detect CPF in the real environ-
mental water sample analysis without the pretreatment of
samples.
CONCLUSIONS
In this work, we have demonstrated a sensitive electrochemical
sensing protocol for the detection of organophosphate pesticide

response of the imprinted PATP-AuNP-gc electrode to 6.0 × 10 -6 M
CPF in 0.05 M PBS (pH ) 6.86) and 0.1 M KCl. Scan rate: 100 mV
s -1 .
Figure 10. Anodic peak current ratio (I s /I 0 ) of the imprinted PATP-
AuNP-gc electrode to 6.0 × 10 -6 M CPF in the presence of 6.0 ×
10 -5 M MP, MA, TAP, CP and 2,4-D, respectively. Preconcentration
time is 10 min before measurement.
Figure 11. Cyclic voltammograms of increasing CPF concentration
in 0.05 M PBS (pH ) 6.86) containing 0.1 M KCl. The inset shows
the calibration curve of CPF. CPF concentration was 0.5, 1, 2, 4, 6,
8, 10, 20, 50 µM, (from bottom to top), respectively. Scan rate: 100
mV s -1 .
248
Analytical Chemistry, Vol. 82, No. 1, January 1, 2010
CPF by a surface molecular self-assembly strategy for electropo-
lymerized molecular imprinting at the AuNP-gc electrode. CPF
molecules assembled on the ATP-modified AuNP-gc electrode
surface were embedded into the imprinted PATP membranes and
formed surface imprinted sites. Meanwhile, the imprinted sites
were further replenished by CPF molecules in the electropoly-
merization precursor mixture. It has clearly been demonstrated
that the cyclic voltammetric response of the imprinted PATP-
AuNP-gc sensor is about 3.2-fold compared to that of the imprinted
PATP-Au sensor and that the detection limit for CPF by the
imprinted PATP-AuNP-gc sensor is about 2 orders of magnitude
lower than that by the imprinted PATP-Au sensor. Moreover, the
imprinted PATP-AuNP-gc sensor also shows specific recognition
selectivity for CPF molecules over other pesticides. Therefore,
this novel, facile strategy reported herein can be further expected
to fabricate various electrochemical sensors for detecting the
pesticide residuals and other environmentally deleterious chemicals.
